One-pot synthesis of secondary amines from aldehydes and primary amines over trifunctional Au-TiO2 as a water adsorbent, acid catalyst and photocatalyst without the use of hydrogen gas Eri Fudo Conceptualization Investigation Formal analysis Writing – original draft Funding acquisition a Yusuke Kiyota Conceptualization Investigation a Ryuto Osawa Conceptualization Investigation b Atsuhiro Tanaka Conceptualization Formal analysis Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition Project administration b Hiroshi Kominami Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition Project administration b ⁎ a Department of Molecular and Material Engineering, Graduate School of Science and Engineering, Kindai University, Kowakae, Higashiosaka, Osaka 577-8502, Japan Department of Molecular and Material Engineering, Graduate School of Science and Engineering, Kindai University Kowakae, Higashiosaka Osaka 577-8502 Japan Department of Molecular and Material Engineering, Graduate School of Science and Engineering, Kindai University, Kowakae, Higashiosaka, Osaka 577–8502, Japan b Department of Applied Chemistry, Faculty of Science and Engineering, Kindai University, Kowakae, Higashiosaka, Osaka 577-8502, Japan Department of Applied Chemistry, Faculty of Science and Engineering, Kindai University Kowakae, Higashiosaka Osaka 577-8502 Japan Department of Applied Chemistry, Faculty of Science and Engineering, Kindai University, Kowakae, Higashiosaka, Osaka 577–8502, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. We succeeded in one-pot synthesis of N-phenylbenzylamine (PBA) from benzaldehyde (BAD) and aniline (AN) over titanium(IV) oxide having a gold (Au) cocatalyst (Au-TiO2) without the use of hydrogen gas. This process consists of two steps: 1) formation of benzylideneaniline (BAN) and water by condensation of AN and BAD, a step that is a thermal reaction and results in an equilibrium being reached, and 2) photocatalytic hydrogenation of BAN to PBA through a hydrogen transfer reaction from alcohol. Reactions under various conditions revealed that TiO2 showed bifunctionality in the condensation process as an acid catalyst and an adsorbent of water. Among the cocatalysts examined in this study, Au showed the highest performance for PBA production. Photoirradiation to the system in equilibrium containing Au-TiO2 produced PBA in a yield of about 92%. We found that TiO2 having a gold (Au) cocatalyst (Au-TiO2) works as a trifunctional catalytic material, i.e., an acid catalyst and water adsorbent for the first step and a photocatalyst for the second step. Expandability of this reaction system in production of halogen-substituted PBA and selection of alcohol was investigated. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords TiO2 Photocatalyst One-pot synthesis Primary amines H2-free Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Secondary amines are important compounds that are widely used in the synthesis of pharmaceuticals and pesticides [1]. These compounds are synthesized by various methods including 1) N-alkylation of primary amines with alkyl halides (Hofmann alkylation), 2) reductive amination of aldehydes or saturated aliphatic ketones (Borch reductive amination) [2,3], 3) hydrogenation of imines [4] and 4) N-alkylation of primary amines with alcohols. The first method is the most common and straightforward route; however, this method also produces tertiary amines and quaternary ammonium salts. The second method requires a toxic borohydride as the reducing reagent. The third method requires reducing reagents such as metal hydrides, silane compounds and hydrogen (H2). After the use of metal hydrides and silane compounds, residues derived from these reagents also form, resulting in a decrease in the atom efficiency of the reaction. On the other hand, H2 is a typical clean reducing reagent that produces no by-product in principle. However, H2 should be treated with care because it reacts with O2 even at room temperature. The fourth method, in which an alcohol and a noble metal are used as the alkylating agent and catalyst, respectively, has been reported as an alternative environmentally friendly synthetic method. In this method, three catalytic steps occur: (1) conversion of alcohols to aldehydes and hydrogen over a metal complex catalyst (dehydrogenation), (2) formation of imines by catalytic condensation of aldehydes and primary amines and (3) hydrogenation of imines to amines. The problem with this system is that homogeneous catalysts such as Pt, Ru and Ir have been used and the recovery and reuse of these catalysts are therefore difficult [5,6]. A photocatalytic reaction is one of environmentally friendly methods for a material conversion reaction under mild conditions [7]. Titanium(IV) oxide (TiO2) is one of the most well-known and promising semiconductor photocatalysts and is harmless to the human body. Since TiO2 is a solid substance, it can be easily recovered from the reaction mixture. When TiO2 is irradiated with light of which the energy is larger than the bandgap, electrons in the valence band are excited to the conduction band, resulting in the formation of holes in the valence band. Since TiO2 simultaneously causes reduction and oxidation reactions under UV light irradiation, it can be considered that TiO2 simultaneously works as reducing and oxidizing agents. Therefore, it is possible to conduct an environmentally friendly redox reaction, i.e., target reduction and oxidation of alcohols and biomass having a low environmental impact without the use of metal hydrides, silane compounds and H2. Metal nanoparticles introduced to a photocatalyst as a cocatalyst change the catalytic performance and promote various reactions at room temperature and under H2 gas-free conditions [8–11]. TiO2 is also known as a solid Lewis acid catalyst [12] that functions even in the presence of water. Shiraishi et al. [13] reported the production of a secondary amine, N-phenylbenzylamine (PBA), by N-alkylation of aniline (AN) with benzyl alcohol over TiO2 having a palladium (Pd) cocatalyst. However, since benzyl alcohol was used as the solvent, large amounts of benzaldehyde (BAD) and H2 were produced and remained unused for production of a secondary amine. In addition, toluene was formed as a by-product probably due to the strong catalytic activity of the Pd cocatalyst loaded on TiO2. Therefore, a more environmentally friendly photocatalytic process with minimal amounts of the N-alkylation reagent and byproduct(s) for the production of secondary amines is highly desired. In this study, we examined a one-pot synthesis of PBA and substituted PBA in which benzaldehyde was used as the N-alkylation reagent. Since benzyl alcohol is generally produced from BAD, the use of BAD instead of benzyl alcohol has the following advantages: 1) the process is free from fruitless consumption of the N-alkylation reagent as observed in the case of benzyl alcohol and 2) inexpensive and safe alcohols can be used as the hydrogen source, thus making the process more environmentally friendly. The process consists of two steps: 1) formation of benzylideneaniline (BAN) and water by condensation of AN and BAD ( Scheme 1), a step that is a thermal reaction and results in an equilibrium being reached, and 2) photocatalytic hydrogenation of BAN to PBA together with dehydrogenation of alcohol ( Scheme 2). Therefore, multi-functionality is required for the catalyst materials to obtain PBA in this process ( Scheme 3). Here we found that TiO2 having a gold (Au) cocatalyst (Au-TiO2) works as a trifunctional catalytic material, i.e., an acid catalyst and water adsorbent for the first step and a photocatalyst for the second step. Effects of metal cocatalysts, time courses of compounds during the reaction and expandability of Au-TiO2 were investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of metal-loaded TiO2 (M-TiO2) by the photodeposition method Various metals (Au, Cu, Pd, Ag, Rh and Pt) (1 wt%) were loaded on TiO2 (MT-150A, ca 100 m2 g−1, Tayca, Osaka, Japan) as cocatalysts by using the photodeposition method. The weight of each metal was based on the total weight of M-TiO2. The metal sources were HAuCl4, CuCl2, PdCl2, AgNO3, RhCl3 and H2PtCl6, respectively. The concentration of the aqueous solution was ca. 1 g dm−3. TiO2 powder (99 mg) was suspended in a mixture of methanol (1 cm3), the solution of the metal source (1 cm3) and water (8 cm3) in a test tube. The test tube was sealed with a rubber septum under argon (Ar). A 400 W high-pressure mercury arc (KPI, Hyogo, Japan) was used as the source of UV light to reduce the metal source to a metallic state on the surface of TiO2. Photodeposition was performed for 1 h at 293 K in a water bath. The metal-loaded TiO2 (M-TiO2) was washed with distilled water and then dried for 1.5 h under vacuum. Atomic absorption spectrometry for the liquid phase after the photodeposition revealed that the metals were almost quantitatively loaded on TiO2. 2.2 Characterization Morphology and particle size of the prepared samples were observed under a transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEM-2100 F, JEOL, Tokyo) operated at 200 kV that was equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS) in the Joint Research Center (JRC) at Kindai University. An X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectrum of the Au-TiO2 sample was measured using a PHI VersaProbe 4 (ULVAC-PHI, Kanagawa) in JRC to obtain information about the electron states of Au, Ti and O in the sample. A washer made of stainless steel (SUS316) was filled with Au-TiO2 powder and set on a silver sample holder by using conductive carbon tape. Then the sample was analyzed using Al Kα radiation in a vacuum chamber in 0.1-eV steps. The position of the carbon peak (284.6 eV) for C 1 s was used to calibrate the binding energy. The amount of water adsorbed on the TiO2 powder was determined by Thermo plus EVO2 TG-DTA8122 (Rigaku, Tokyo) under an N2 flow in JRC. Before the analysis, TiO2 was stored in a humidistat (a desiccator with a saturated aqueous solution of potassium chloride, 84.34 ± 0.26% at 25°C) for 7 days until the adsorption of water reached an equilibrium at room temperature. 2.3 One-pot synthesis of N-phenylbenzylamine (PBA) from benzaldehyde and aniline over M-TiO2 Fifty mg of M-TiO2 was suspended in 5 cm3 of acetonitrile (ACN) containing 2-propanol (100 μmol) in a test tube. After sealing the tube with a rubber septum under argon (Ar), an ACN solution containing BAD (50 μmol) and an ACN solution containing AN (45 μmol) were quickly injected into the test tube in that order. The suspension was stirred in the dark for 1 h until the condensation of AN and BAD reached an equilibrium. Then the suspension in the test tube was photoirradiated with a high-pressure mercury arc at 293 K. The compounds (BAD, AN, BAN and PBA) in the liquid phase were analyzed by an FID-type gas chromatograph (GC-2025, Shimadzu) with a DB-1 column. Unreacted 2-propanol and acetone that was formed in the liquid phase were analyzed by an FID-type gas chromatograph (GC-2025, Shimadzu) with a DB-WAX column. Toluene was used as the internal standard sample. Hydrogen (H2) in the gas phase was analyzed by a TCD-type gas chromatograph (GC-8A, Shimadzu) with an MS-5A column. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effects of catalyst and temperature on condensation of AN and BAD in the dark To obtain information on the first step, condensation of almost equimolar AN and BAD (reaction T) was examined in the presence and absence of a catalyst in the dark. Fig. 1(a) shows the result in the absence of a catalyst. Only a small amount of BAN was produced. This result indicates that catalyst-free homogeneous condensation of AN and BAD was slow and the equilibrium was reached at a low conversion rate of the starting substrates (AN and BAD). The equilibrium constant (K c) of the condensation was calculated to be 9.0 × 10−3 from the concentrations of AN, BAD and BAN after 2 h, assuming that the concentrations of BAN and water were the same. We noted that the rate of BAN formation was greatly improved in the presence of pristine TiO2, i.e., an equilibrium was reached after 30 min, as shown in Fig. 1(b). The result means that TiO2 works as an acid catalyst. Another important effect of TiO2 is that the presence of TiO2 increased the yield of BAN; in other words, TiO2 shifted the equilibrium to the product side. The amount of water in the liquid phase was calculated to be 0.54 μmol from K c (= 9.0 ×10−3) and concentrations of AN, BAD and BAN after 2 h, indicating that water produced by the condensation of AN and BAD was removed from the liquid phase. In other words, most of the water (15 μmol) was absorbed on TiO2 because TiO2 used in this study (MT-150A) has a large specific surface area of ca 100 m2g−1 and the surface property is hydrophilic. To investigate the performance of TiO2 for adsorption of water, TiO2 was stored in a humidistat (relative humidity of 84.34 +0.26% at 25 °C) for 7 days, and the amount of water desorbed from TiO2 under an N2 flow at around 27 °C was determined to be 7.32% ( Fig. 2). The value corresponds to 203 μmol per 50 mg TiO2 used in the photocatalytic reaction, which was much larger than the amount of water produced during the condensation reaction (15 μmol, Fig. 1(b)). This result reveals that TiO2 also works as an adsorbent of water. Fig. 1(c) shows the result in the presence of Au-TiO2. Almost the same results for pristine TiO2 and Au-TiO2 mean that Au nanoparticles had no effect on the equilibrium and the rates of condensation of AN and BAD in the dark. The results shown in Fig. 1 also indicate that an equilibrium was reached after 60 min fx1 . 3.2 Effects of metal cocatalysts on photocatalytic production of PBA from AN and BAD via BAN Table 1 summarizes the results for production of PBA from AN and BAD in ACN suspensions of TiO2 having various cocatalysts (Au, Ag, Cu, Pd, Rh and Pt) under irradiation of UV light for 60 min after condensation of AN and BAD in the dark for 60 min. As shown in the previous section, condensation of AN and BAD occurred in the dark and ca. 15 μmol of BAN was present in the reaction mixture before the light irradiation. When AN, BAD and 2-propanol dissolved in ACN were photoirradiated in the absence of a catalyst, no products were observed, indicating that no photochemical reaction occurred (Entry 8). In the case of TiO2 free from a cocatalyst, neither PBA nor H2 was produced (Entry 1), and, instead, the color of TiO2 changed from white to blue due to formation of Ti3+ by self-reduction of Ti4+. Since the potential of the conduction band of TiO2 (MT-150A) is close to that of proton (H+) reduction, a cocatalyst is necessary for both BAN hydrogenation and H2 formation. In the cases of TiO2 having cocatalysts, H2 evolution was observed due to simple dehydrogenation of 2-propanol. The Ag cocatalyst showed weak performance for BAN hydrogenation and H2 formation probably due to a weak interaction with the CN double bond of BAN and the large hydrogen overvoltage (Entry 3). Rh-TiO2 and Pt-TiO2 showed no or negligible activity in BAN hydrogenation under light irradiation, although they were very active for H2 evolution due to the small hydrogen overvoltage (Entries 6 and 7). All of the 2-propanol (100 μmol) was used for H2 formation in the case of Pt-TiO2. In contrast to metal-free TiO2 and TiO2 having Ag, Rh and Pt, PBA was produced when Au-TiO2, Cu-TiO2 and Pd-TiO2 were used after light irradiation for 1 h (Entries 2, 4, 5), indicating that these metals work as cocatalysts for photocatalytic hydrogenation of BAN (Scheme 2). In the case of Pd-TiO2, the selectivity for PBA production was lower than that over Au-TiO2 and Cu-TiO2 due to the by-product. Among the cocatalysts examined in this study, Au showed the highest performance for PBA production. Therefore, Au-TiO2 was investigated in detail. 3.3 Characterization of Au-TiO2 TEM image of TiO2 is shown in Fig. 3(a), indicating that the morphology of TiO2 was rod-like. TEM images Au-TiO2 are shown in Fig. 3(b) and Fig. 3(c). From these TEM of Au-TiO2, we confirmed that fine Au particles were loaded on TiO2. From the size distribution of Au particles loaded on TiO2 (Fig. 3(d)), the average diameter of the particles was determined to be 10.4 nm. STEM-EDS analysis of Au-TiO2 (Fig. 3(e)) revealed that the particle in the center of the STEM photograph was Au. To investigate the electron states of Au, Ti and O in Au-TiO2, Au-TiO2 was analyzed by using XPS and spectra around the Au 4 f, Ti 2p and O 1 s components are shown in Fig. 3(f). In the XPS spectrum of Au 4 f, two peaks were observed at 83.3 and 87.1 eV, which are assignable to Au0 [14]. In the XPS spectrum of Ti 2p, peaks appeared at 458.5 eV (Ti 2p3/2) and 464.0 eV (Ti 2p1/2). The difference in binding energy of Ti 2p3/2 and that of Ti 2p1/2 was 5.5 eV, which can be assigned to the typical Ti4+–O bonds in TiO2. A peak due to O 1 s was observed at 529.9 eV, which can be attributed to lattice O in TiO2 [15]. 3.4 Photocatalytic production of PBA from AN and BAD via BAN in an ACN suspension of Au-TiO2 The effects of different amounts of the Au cocatalyst on PBA production from AN and BAD dissolved in ACN were investigated ( Fig. 4) and the maximum yield of PBA was obtained at 1 wt%, although the effect of Au content was not large. Results of TEM and XRD analysis of Au-TiO2 (Au: 1, 3 and 5 wt%) were shown in Figs. S1 and S2, respectively. TEM observation revealed that the size of Au particle increases with increasing the Au content. In the XRD patterns, peaks due to the rutile phase were obtained in all samples and peaks due to Au were observed only in the pattern of the 5 wt% sample. From the result, it is expected that the surface area of Au particles gradually increases with increasing the Au content. However, the photocatalytic activity for PBA formation gradually decreased with increase in the Au content. These results suggest that the surface area of Au particles has a lesser effect on the photocatalytic activity. A parameter having an effect on the catalytic performance should be clarified in the next study. Fig. 5 shows the time course of the condensation reaction of AN and BAD in the dark for 60 min and the subsequent hydrogenation of BAN to PBA in an ACN suspension of 1 wt% Au-TiO2 in the presence of 2-propanol. During the condensation reaction in the dark, the amount of 2-propanol did not change because it does not contribute to the condensation. Photoirradiation to the system in equilibrium produced PBA and acetone together with the consumption of 2-propanol, indicating that BAN was hydrogenated by hydrogen species derived from 2-propanol (Scheme 2). The amounts of AN and BAD decreased; however, the amount of BAN did not increase. Along with the formation of PBA, H2 was also produced as a by-product. These results indicate that the reaction rates decrease in the order of photocatalytic dehydrogenation of 2-propanol to acetone > photocatalytic hydrogenation of BAN to PBA > condensation of AN and BAD to BAN and water. BAD and AN were almost completely consumed after 4 h (photoirradiation for 3 h) and PBA was obtained in a yield of about 92%. In order to reveal the total stoichiometry of the redox reaction, redox balance (RB) was calculated by using Eq. (1) and the values of RB are also shown in Fig. 5. The values of RB were almost unity regardless of the irradiation time. These results indicate that the reductions (formation of PBA and H2) and the oxidation (formation of acetone) proceeded with a high stoichiometry. (1) Redox Balance ( RB ) = 2 × n PBA + 2 × n ( H 2 ) 2 × n ( acetone ) where n(PBA), n(H2), and n(acetone) are the amounts of PBA, H2, and acetone during. the photocatalytic reaction, respectively. After the reaction for 4 h, Au-TiO2 was recovered from the reaction mixture and observed by TEM. Fig. 6 shows a TEM image and the size distribution of Au. The average size of Au particles after the reaction was determined to be 9.5 nm. The size was almost the same as that before the reaction (10.4 nm, Fig. 3), indicating that Au nanoparticles loaded on TiO2 were stable. In order to demonstrate the performance of a photocatalyst, it is important to show whether a photocatalyst can be reused several times. After the photocatalytic condensation and hydrogenation reaction from AN and BAD to PBA, Au-TiO2 powder was separated from the reaction mixture by filtration. After washing with water, the Au-TiO2 powder was used again for the same reaction. In the second and third cycles, the yield of PBA was also maintained as shown in Fig. S3. These results indicate that the Au-TiO2 photocatalyst was stable and reusable in this reaction at least three times. Since simple H2 evolution occurred in the present system, the use of an excess amount (100 µmol) of 2-propnaol larger than the stoichiometric amount (ca. 50 µmol) was the key for a high PBA yield. Table 2 shows the effects of different amounts of 2-propanol on hydrogenation of BAN (50 µmol) in an ACN suspension of 1 wt% Au-TiO2. When the reagent BAN, not produced from condensation, was used, small amounts of AN and BAD were produced by hydrolysis of BAN. In the presence of 100 µmol of 2-propanol, most of the BAN was hydrogenated to PBA and equimolar amounts of AN and BAD were observed. When 50 µmol of 2-propanol was used, the yield of PBA decreased and the amount of BAD was smaller than that of AN, suggesting that a part of BAD was used as the hydrogen source (hole scavenger) for BAN hydrogenation due to consumption of 2-propanol. Therefore, the optimum amount of 2-propanol was determined to be 100 µmol in this reaction system. The excellence of Au-TiO2 as a photocatalyst is that PBA was not consumed by further photoirradiation, as shown in Fig. 5. To further confirm this, an ACN suspension of Au-TiO2 containing PBA (50 μmol) and 2-propnaol (100 μmol) was photoirradiated under the same conditions and the results are shown in Table 3. After 1 h, 2-propnaol was almost completely consumed, while 100 μmol of acetone and H2 were produced with no PBA being consumed, indicating that only conversion of 2-propanol to acetone and H2 occurred. To confirm the hydrogen species used for the hydrogenation of BAN, a reaction of BAN in an ACN suspension of Au-TiO2 was carried out in the dark under H2 (1 atm, ca. 1300 μmol) at room temperature. As shown in Fig. 7, BAN was not hydrogenated to PBA but was hydrolyzed to BAD and AN with a small amount of water originally dissolved in the solvent ACN. This result clarifies that H2 in the gas phase was not dissociatively adsorbed on Au nanoparticles in the dark at room temperature and cannot be the active species for hydrogenation of BAN. Therefore, it can be concluded that the hydrogen species formed on Au nanoparticles via reduction of H+ by photogenerated electrons are the active species for hydrogenation of BAN. Table 4 shows the effect of substitution with a halogen atom in AN (X-AN) or BAD (X-BAD) on the production of substituted PBA (X-PBA) in an ACN suspension of 1 wt% Au-TiO2 in the presence of 2-propanol. The results for condensation in equilibrium in the dark after 1 h are shown in the upper column in Table 4 and the results for hydrogenation of imines under light irradiation for 4 h are shown in the lower column in Table 4. In the reaction of AN and X-BAD (Entries 2–5), the equilibrium points shifted to the imine sides in the dark and these imines may be thermodynamically stable due to the electron-withdrawing effect of halogen atoms of X-BAD on the nucleophilic addition of the lone pairs of nitrogen atoms of AN to carbonyl carbon atoms of X-BAD. Since the duration of photoirradiation (4 h) was sufficient for hydrogenation of imines, conversion of AN and X-BAN was the almost same within experimental errors, resulting in the formation of X-PBA with high yields. However, a small amount of halogen-free PBA was produced due to elimination of halogen atoms from X-BAD and/or X-PBA during photoirradiation. In the reaction of X-AN and BAD (Entries 6–9), the equilibrium points shifted to the left sides in the dark and these imines may be thermodynamically unstable due to the electron-withdrawing effect of halogen atoms of X-AN, which decreases the electron density of the lone pairs of nitrogen atoms of X-AN. Even after irradiation for 4 h, AN and BAN remained in the reaction mixture. The double-bond character of N = C in these imines decreased and a cationic character, i.e., =N–C+− structure, would be stabilized due to the larger electron negativity of nitrogen atoms than that of carbon atoms and the electron-withdrawing effect of halogen atoms of X-AN. These characteristics probably make hydrogenation difficult. In all of the experiments reported up to here, 2-propanol was used as the hydrogen source for hydrogenation because quantitative analysis and discussion of the oxidized product, i.e., acetone, is easy. To examine the possibility of the present method being used for secondary amine production, various alcohols were used in addition to 2-propanol, although quantitative analysis of corresponding carbonyl compounds was difficult. Fig. 8 shows the results for production of PBA from AN and BAN in ACN suspensions of Au-TiO2 in the dark for 1 h and subsequent light irradiation for 1 h. In all cases, PBA was produced, which means that various alcohols can be used as the hydrogen source for this reaction system. 4 Conclusion We examined a one-pot synthesis of PBA and substituted PBA from AN in which BAD was used as the N-alkylation reagent without the use of H2. This process consists of two steps: 1) formation of BAN and water by condensation of AN and BAD, a step that is a thermal reaction and results in an equilibrium being reached, and 2) hydrogenation of BAN to PBA together with dehydrogenation of alcohol. The rate of BAN formation was greatly improved in the presence of TiO2, i.e., an equilibrium was reached after 30 min. Another important effect of TiO2 is that the presence of TiO2 increased the yield of BAN; in other words, TiO2 shifted the equilibrium to the product side. These results revealed that TiO2 showed bifunctionality in the condensation process as an acid catalyst and an adsorbent of water. Photoirradiation to the system in equilibrium containing Au-TiO2 produced PBA and acetone together with the consumption of 2-propanol, indicating that BAN was hydrogenated by hydrogen species derived from 2-propanol. BAD and AN were almost completely consumed after 4 h (photoirradiation for 3 h) and PBA was obtained in a yield of about 92%, indicating that Au-TiO2 was a trifunctional material in this reaction. Among the cocatalysts examined in this study, Au showed the highest performance for PBA production. Since simple H2 evolution occurred in the present system, the use of an excess amount (100 µmol) of 2-propnaol larger than the stoichiometric amount (ca. 50 µmol) was the key for a high PBA yield. H2 in the gas phase was not dissociatively adsorbed on Au nanoparticles in the dark at room temperature and cannot be the active species for hydrogenation of BAN. This reaction system can be applied to the production of halogen-substituted PBA from corresponding AN and BAN. TEM observation revealed that Au particles having an average diameter of 10.4 nm were loaded on TiO2 and that the size of particles did not change after the reaction. coredata.dc:description: We succeeded in one-pot synthesis of N-phenylbenzylamine (PBA) from benzaldehyde (BAD) and aniline (AN) over titanium(IV) oxide having a gold (Au) cocatalyst (Au-TiO2) without the use of hydrogen gas. This process consists of two steps: 1) formation of benzylideneaniline (BAN) and water by condensation of AN and BAD, a step that is a thermal reaction and results in an equilibrium being reached, and 2) photocatalytic hydrogenation of BAN to PBA through a hydrogen transfer reaction from alcohol. Reactions under various conditions revealed that TiO2 showed bifunctionality in the condensation process as an acid catalyst and an adsorbent of water. Among the cocatalysts examined in this study, Au showed the highest performance for PBA production. Photoirradiation to the system in equilibrium containing Au-TiO2 produced PBA in a yield of about 92%. We found that TiO2 having a gold (Au) cocatalyst (Au-TiO2) works as a trifunctional catalytic material, i.e., an acid catalyst and water adsorbent for the first step and a photocatalyst for the second step. Expandability of this reaction system in production of halogen-substituted PBA and selection of alcohol was investigated.
coredata.dc:title: One-pot synthesis of secondary amines from aldehydes and primary amines over trifunctional Au-TiO2 as a water adsorbent, acid catalyst and photocatalyst without the use of hydrogen gas
